subject: Chemistry
question_text: According to VSEPR theory, what is the primary factor that determines the arrangement of electron pairs around a central atom?

options.a: Maximizing the attraction between the nucleus and electrons.
options.b: Minimizing the electrostatic repulsion between valence electron pairs.
options.c: Maximizing the number of bonds formed.

explanation: The VSEPR model assumes that electron pairs in the valence shell of a central atom will adopt an arrangement that minimizes repulsions between these electron pairs by maximizing the distance between them.[[1](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fchem.libretexts.org%2FBookshelves%2FGeneral_Chemistry%2FMap%253A_Chemistry_-_The_Central_Science_(Brown_et_al.)%2F11%253A_Liquids_and_Intermolecular_Forces%2F11.02%253A_Intermolecular_Forces)][[2](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)] [Source: OpenStax](https://openstax.org/books/chemistry-2e/pages/7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: Which of the following correctly lists the order of electron-pair repulsions from greatest to least?

options.a: bonding pair-bonding pair > lone pair-bonding pair > lone pair-lone pair
options.b: lone pair-lone pair > lone pair-bonding pair > bonding pair-bonding pair
options.c: lone pair-bonding pair > bonding pair-bonding pair > lone pair-lone pair
options.d: bonding pair-bonding pair > lone pair-lone pair > lone pair-bonding pair

explanation: Lone pairs occupy more space than bonding pairs, leading to stronger repulsions.[[1](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fchem.libretexts.org%2FBookshelves%2FGeneral_Chemistry%2FMap%253A_Chemistry_-_The_Central_Science_(Brown_et_al.)%2F11%253A_Liquids_and_Intermolecular_Forces%2F11.02%253A_Intermolecular_Forces)][[2](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)] The order is: lone pair-lone pair > lone pair-bonding pair > bonding pair-bonding pair. [Source: OpenStax](https://openstax.org/books/chemistry-2e/pages/7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: In the VSEPR model, how is a double or triple bond treated when counting regions of electron density?

options.a: A double bond counts as 2 regions; a triple bond counts as 3 regions.
options.b: Multiple bonds are not counted as regions of electron density.
options.c: A single, double, or triple bond each counts as exactly one region of electron density.
options.d: A double bond counts as 1 region, but a triple bond counts as 2 regions.[[1](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fchem.libretexts.org%2FBookshelves%2FGeneral_Chemistry%2FMap%253A_Chemistry_-_The_Central_Science_(Brown_et_al.)%2F11%253A_Liquids_and_Intermolecular_Forces%2F11.02%253A_Intermolecular_Forces)]

explanation: We count the number of regions of electron density (lone pairs and bonds) around the central atom.[[1](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fchem.libretexts.org%2FBookshelves%2FGeneral_Chemistry%2FMap%253A_Chemistry_-_The_Central_Science_(Brown_et_al.)%2F11%253A_Liquids_and_Intermolecular_Forces%2F11.02%253A_Intermolecular_Forces)][[2](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)][[3](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F8-2-hybrid-atomic-orbitals)] A single, double, or triple bond counts as one region of electron density.[[1](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fchem.libretexts.org%2FBookshelves%2FGeneral_Chemistry%2FMap%253A_Chemistry_-_The_Central_Science_(Brown_et_al.)%2F11%253A_Liquids_and_Intermolecular_Forces%2F11.02%253A_Intermolecular_Forces)][[2](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)][[4](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F8-4-molecular-orbital-theory)] [Source: OpenStax](https://openstax.org/books/chemistry-2e/pages/7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: Why are the bond angles in ammonia ($NH_3$) and water ($H_2O$) slightly less than the ideal tetrahedral angle of $109.5^\circ$?

options.a: The atoms are too large to fit the ideal angle.
options.b: Lone pairs occupy a larger region of space than bonding pairs, compressing the bond angles.
options.c: The bonds in these molecules are ionic rather than covalent.
options.d: The central atoms are $sp^2$ hybridized rather than $sp^3$.

explanation: The bond angles are slightly smaller than 109.5° because the lone pair-bonding pair repulsion is greater than the bonding pair-bonding pair repulsion, taking up more space.[[1](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fchem.libretexts.org%2FBookshelves%2FGeneral_Chemistry%2FMap%253A_Chemistry_-_The_Central_Science_(Brown_et_al.)%2F11%253A_Liquids_and_Intermolecular_Forces%2F11.02%253A_Intermolecular_Forces)][[2](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)][[3](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F8-2-hybrid-atomic-orbitals)][[4](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F8-4-molecular-orbital-theory)][[5](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fchem.libretexts.org%2FBookshelves%2FGeneral_Chemistry%2FMap%253A_General_Chemistry_(Petrucci_et_al.)%2F10%253A_Chemical_Bonding_II_-_Valence_Bond_and_Molecular_Orbital_Theory%2F10.02%253A_VSEPR_Theory_and_Molecular_Shapes)] [Source: OpenStax](https://openstax.org/books/chemistry-2e/pages/7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: Predict the molecular structure of Beryllium difluoride ($BeF_2$).
explanation: With two bonds and no lone pairs of electrons on the central atom, the bonds are as far apart as possible (180°), adopting a linear structure.[[1](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fchem.libretexts.org%2FBookshelves%2FGeneral_Chemistry%2FMap%253A_Chemistry_-_The_Central_Science_(Brown_et_al.)%2F11%253A_Liquids_and_Intermolecular_Forces%2F11.02%253A_Intermolecular_Forces)][[2](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)] [Source: OpenStax](https://openstax.org/books/chemistry-2e/pages/7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: What is the molecular structure of Boron trichloride ($BCl_3$)?
explanation: $BCl_3$ contains three bonds and no lone pairs.[[1](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fchem.libretexts.org%2FBookshelves%2FGeneral_Chemistry%2FMap%253A_Chemistry_-_The_Central_Science_(Brown_et_al.)%2F11%253A_Liquids_and_Intermolecular_Forces%2F11.02%253A_Intermolecular_Forces)][[2](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)][[3](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F8-2-hybrid-atomic-orbitals)] The arrangement of three regions of high electron density gives a trigonal planar geometry.[[1](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fchem.libretexts.org%2FBookshelves%2FGeneral_Chemistry%2FMap%253A_Chemistry_-_The_Central_Science_(Brown_et_al.)%2F11%253A_Liquids_and_Intermolecular_Forces%2F11.02%253A_Intermolecular_Forces)][[2](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)][[3](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F8-2-hybrid-atomic-orbitals)] [Source: OpenStax](https://openstax.org/books/chemistry-2e/pages/7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: Methane ($CH_4$) has four bonding pairs and no lone pairs. What is its molecular structure?
explanation: Methane has four bonding pairs around the central carbon atom; the electron-pair geometry is tetrahedral, as is the molecular structure. [Source: OpenStax](https://openstax.org/books/chemistry-2e/pages/7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: Ammonia ($NH_3$) has a tetrahedral electron-pair geometry. What is its *molecular* structure?
explanation: Ammonia has four electron pairs (tetrahedral geometry), but one is a lone pair.[[1](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fchem.libretexts.org%2FBookshelves%2FGeneral_Chemistry%2FMap%253A_Chemistry_-_The_Central_Science_(Brown_et_al.)%2F11%253A_Liquids_and_Intermolecular_Forces%2F11.02%253A_Intermolecular_Forces)][[2](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)][[3](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F8-2-hybrid-atomic-orbitals)] The molecular structure is trigonal pyramidal.[[1](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fchem.libretexts.org%2FBookshelves%2FGeneral_Chemistry%2FMap%253A_Chemistry_-_The_Central_Science_(Brown_et_al.)%2F11%253A_Liquids_and_Intermolecular_Forces%2F11.02%253A_Intermolecular_Forces)][[2](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)] [Source: OpenStax](https://openstax.org/books/chemistry-2e/pages/7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: What is the molecular structure of a water molecule ($H_2O$)?
explanation: Water has four regions of electron density (two bonds, two lone pairs).[[1](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fchem.libretexts.org%2FBookshelves%2FGeneral_Chemistry%2FMap%253A_Chemistry_-_The_Central_Science_(Brown_et_al.)%2F11%253A_Liquids_and_Intermolecular_Forces%2F11.02%253A_Intermolecular_Forces)][[2](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)][[3](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F8-2-hybrid-atomic-orbitals)] The electron geometry is tetrahedral, but the molecular structure is bent.[[1](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fchem.libretexts.org%2FBookshelves%2FGeneral_Chemistry%2FMap%253A_Chemistry_-_The_Central_Science_(Brown_et_al.)%2F11%253A_Liquids_and_Intermolecular_Forces%2F11.02%253A_Intermolecular_Forces)][[2](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)] [Source: OpenStax](https://openstax.org/books/chemistry-2e/pages/7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: Which molecular structure is associated with Phosphorus pentafluoride ($PF_5$)?
explanation: Any molecule with five electron pairs around the central atom including no lone pairs will be trigonal bipyramidal.[[1](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fchem.libretexts.org%2FBookshelves%2FGeneral_Chemistry%2FMap%253A_Chemistry_-_The_Central_Science_(Brown_et_al.)%2F11%253A_Liquids_and_Intermolecular_Forces%2F11.02%253A_Intermolecular_Forces)][[2](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)] $PF_5$ is a common example.[[1](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fchem.libretexts.org%2FBookshelves%2FGeneral_Chemistry%2FMap%253A_Chemistry_-_The_Central_Science_(Brown_et_al.)%2F11%253A_Liquids_and_Intermolecular_Forces%2F11.02%253A_Intermolecular_Forces)][[2](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)] [Source: OpenStax](https://openstax.org/books/chemistry-2e/pages/7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: Sulfur tetrafluoride ($SF_4$) has 5 regions of electron density, including one lone pair. What is its shape?
explanation: With 5 regions, the electron geometry is trigonal bipyramidal. The lone pair occupies an equatorial position to minimize repulsion, resulting in a seesaw structure.[[1](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fchem.libretexts.org%2FBookshelves%2FGeneral_Chemistry%2FMap%253A_Chemistry_-_The_Central_Science_(Brown_et_al.)%2F11%253A_Liquids_and_Intermolecular_Forces%2F11.02%253A_Intermolecular_Forces)][[2](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)] [Source: OpenStax](https://openstax.org/books/chemistry-2e/pages/7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: Chlorine trifluoride ($ClF_3$) has 5 electron domains (3 bonds, 2 lone pairs). What is its molecular structure?
explanation: The stable structure puts the two lone pairs in equatorial locations of the trigonal bipyramid, giving a T-shaped molecular structure.[[1](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fchem.libretexts.org%2FBookshelves%2FGeneral_Chemistry%2FMap%253A_Chemistry_-_The_Central_Science_(Brown_et_al.)%2F11%253A_Liquids_and_Intermolecular_Forces%2F11.02%253A_Intermolecular_Forces)][[2](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)] [Source: OpenStax](https://openstax.org/books/chemistry-2e/pages/7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: Xenon difluoride ($XeF_2$) has 5 regions of electron density (2 bonds, 3 lone pairs). What is its shape?
explanation: With 3 lone pairs in the equatorial positions of a trigonal bipyramid, the remaining two bonds are axial, forming a linear structure. [Source: OpenStax](https://openstax.org/books/chemistry-2e/pages/7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: Sulfur hexafluoride ($SF_6$) has six bonding pairs and no lone pairs. What is its geometry?
explanation: Six regions form an octahedral geometry. $SF_6$ is octahedral.[[1](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fchem.libretexts.org%2FBookshelves%2FGeneral_Chemistry%2FMap%253A_Chemistry_-_The_Central_Science_(Brown_et_al.)%2F11%253A_Liquids_and_Intermolecular_Forces%2F11.02%253A_Intermolecular_Forces)][[2](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)][[3](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F8-2-hybrid-atomic-orbitals)] [Source: OpenStax](https://openstax.org/books/chemistry-2e/pages/7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: Xenon tetrafluoride ($XeF_4$) has an octahedral electron geometry with two lone pairs. What is its molecular structure?
explanation: To minimize repulsions, the two lone pairs occupy opposite sides of the octahedron (180° apart), resulting in a square planar structure.[[1](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fchem.libretexts.org%2FBookshelves%2FGeneral_Chemistry%2FMap%253A_Chemistry_-_The_Central_Science_(Brown_et_al.)%2F11%253A_Liquids_and_Intermolecular_Forces%2F11.02%253A_Intermolecular_Forces)][[2](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)] [Source: OpenStax](https://openstax.org/books/chemistry-2e/pages/7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: What is the molecular structure of $XeOF_4$, which has an octahedral electron-group geometry with one lone pair?
explanation: An atom with five bonds and a lone pair in an octahedral geometry adopts a square pyramidal molecular structure.[[1](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fchem.libretexts.org%2FBookshelves%2FGeneral_Chemistry%2FMap%253A_Chemistry_-_The_Central_Science_(Brown_et_al.)%2F11%253A_Liquids_and_Intermolecular_Forces%2F11.02%253A_Intermolecular_Forces)][[2](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)][[3](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F8-2-hybrid-atomic-orbitals)] [Source: OpenStax](https://openstax.org/books/chemistry-2e/pages/7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: Which orbitals are mixed to form $sp$ hybrid orbitals?

options.a: One s orbital and two p orbitals
options.b: One s orbital and one p orbital
options.d: One s orbital and three p orbitals

explanation: This hybridization process involves mixing of the valence s orbital with one of the valence p orbitals to yield two equivalent sp hybrid orbitals.[[1](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fchem.libretexts.org%2FBookshelves%2FGeneral_Chemistry%2FMap%253A_Chemistry_-_The_Central_Science_(Brown_et_al.)%2F11%253A_Liquids_and_Intermolecular_Forces%2F11.02%253A_Intermolecular_Forces)][[2](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F7-6-molecular-structure-and-polarity)][[3](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F8-2-hybrid-atomic-orbitals)][[4](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F8-4-molecular-orbital-theory)] [Source: OpenStax](https://openstax.org/books/chemistry-2e/pages/8-2-hybrid-atomic-orbitals)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: In the linear molecule $BeCl_2$, what is the hybridization of the central Beryllium atom?
explanation: The beryllium atom in a gaseous $BeCl_2$ molecule exhibits $sp$ hybridization, corresponding to two regions of electron density.[[1](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fchem.libretexts.org%2FBookshelves%2FGeneral_Chemistry%2FMap%253A_Chemistry_-_The_Central_Science_(Brown_et_al.)%2F11%253A_Liquids_and_Intermolecular_Forces%2F11.02%253A_Intermolecular_Forces)][[3](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F8-2-hybrid-atomic-orbitals)] [Source: OpenStax](https://openstax.org/books/chemistry-2e/pages/8-2-hybrid-atomic-orbitals)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: The Boron atom in $BH_3$ has a trigonal planar geometry. What is its hybridization?
explanation: The trigonal planar structure suggests $sp^2$ hybridization, resulting from the mixing of one s orbital and two p orbitals. [Source: OpenStax](https://openstax.org/books/chemistry-2e/pages/8-2-hybrid-atomic-orbitals)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: What hybridization is exhibited by the carbon atom in methane ($CH_4$)?
explanation: The carbon atom in methane exhibits $sp^3$ hybridization, forming four identical orbitals directed to the corners of a tetrahedron.[[1](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fchem.libretexts.org%2FBookshelves%2FGeneral_Chemistry%2FMap%253A_Chemistry_-_The_Central_Science_(Brown_et_al.)%2F11%253A_Liquids_and_Intermolecular_Forces%2F11.02%253A_Intermolecular_Forces)][[3](https://www.google.com/url?sa=E&q=https%3A%2F%2Fopenstax.org%2Fbooks%2Fchemistry-2e%2Fpages%2F8-2-hybrid-atomic-orbitals)] [Source: OpenStax](https://openstax.org/books/chemistry-2e/pages/8-2-hybrid-atomic-orbitals)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: Phosphorus pentachloride ($PCl_5$) has five bonding pairs. Which set of hybrid orbitals is used?
explanation: We use the 3s orbital, the three 3p orbitals, and one of the 3d orbitals to form the set of five $sp^3d$ hybrid orbitals. [Source: OpenStax](https://openstax.org/books/chemistry-2e/pages/8-2-hybrid-atomic-orbitals)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: Which hybridization allows Sulfur in $SF_6$ to bond to six fluorine atoms?
explanation: To bond six fluorine atoms, the 3s orbital, the three 3p orbitals, and two of the 3d orbitals form six equivalent $sp^3d^2$ hybrid orbitals. [Source: OpenStax](https://openstax.org/books/chemistry-2e/pages/8-2-hybrid-atomic-orbitals)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: How is Bond Order calculated in Molecular Orbital Theory?

options.a: (Number of bonding electrons + Number of antibonding electrons) / 2
options.b: (Number of bonding electrons - Number of antibonding electrons) / 2
options.c: Number of bonding electrons - Number of antibonding electrons
options.d: (Number of antibonding electrons - Number of bonding electrons) / 2

explanation: The bond order is defined as one-half the net difference between the number of bonding and antibonding electrons. [Source: OpenStax](https://openstax.org/books/chemistry-2e/pages/8-4-molecular-orbital-theory)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: Why is the oxygen molecule ($O_2$) paramagnetic according to MO Theory?

options.a: It has an odd number of electrons.
options.b: It contains unpaired electrons in the $\pi^*$ (pi antibonding) orbitals.
options.c: All its electrons are paired in $\sigma$ bonding orbitals.
options.d: It has a bond order of 2.5.

explanation: The molecular orbital diagram shows that $O_2$ has two unpaired electrons in the degenerate $\pi^*_{2p}$ orbitals, which explains its paramagnetism. [Source: OpenStax](https://openstax.org/books/chemistry-2e/pages/8-4-molecular-orbital-theory)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: Why does the dihelium molecule ($He_2$) not exist in a stable form?
explanation: With two electrons in the bonding orbital and two in the antibonding orbital, the bond order is $(2-2)/2 = 0$. A bond order of zero indicates that no bond is formed. [Source: OpenStax](https://openstax.org/books/chemistry-2e/pages/8-4-molecular-orbital-theory)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: In MO theory, the side-by-side overlap of two $p​$ orbitals results in which type of orbital?

options.b: Pi ($\pi$) bonding and Pi antibonding ($\pi^*$) orbitals

explanation: The side-by-side overlap of two p orbitals gives rise to a pi ($\pi$) bonding molecular orbital and a $\pi^*$ antibonding molecular orbital. [Source: OpenStax](https://openstax.org/books/chemistry-2e/pages/8-4-molecular-orbital-theory)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: Which elements must hydrogen be bonded to for Hydrogen Bonding to occur?
explanation: Hydrogen bonds form when hydrogen is covalently bonded to one of the three most electronegative elements: Nitrogen (N), Oxygen (O), or Fluorine (F). [Source: Chem LibreTexts](https://chem.libretexts.org/Bookshelves/General_Chemistry/Map%3A_Chemistry_-_The_Central_Science_(Brown_et_al.)/11%3A_Liquids_and_Intermolecular_Forces/11.02%3A_Intermolecular_Forces)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: Which intermolecular force is present in all molecules, regardless of polarity?
explanation: London dispersion forces (also called induced dipole-induced dipole forces) exist between all atoms and molecules. [Source: Chem LibreTexts](https://chem.libretexts.org/Bookshelves/General_Chemistry/Map%3A_Chemistry_-_The_Central_Science_(Brown_et_al.)/11%3A_Liquids_and_Intermolecular_Forces/11.02%3A_Intermolecular_Forces)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: Why does $n​$-pentane have a higher boiling point ($36.1^\circ C$) than its isomer neopentane ($9.5^\circ C$)?

options.c: $n​$-pentane has a larger surface area for contact, increasing London dispersion forces.
options.d: Neopentane has a higher molar mass.

explanation: The linear shape of n-pentane provides a greater surface area for intermolecular contact compared to the spherical shape of neopentane, resulting in stronger London dispersion forces. [Source: Chem LibreTexts](https://chem.libretexts.org/Bookshelves/General_Chemistry/Map%3A_Chemistry_-_The_Central_Science_(Brown_et_al.)/11%3A_Liquids_and_Intermolecular_Forces/11.02%3A_Intermolecular_Forces)

subject: Chemistry
question_text: Which of the following compounds is expected to have the highest boiling point?
explanation: Acetone is a polar molecule with dipole-dipole interactions, which are stronger than the London dispersion forces found in the nonpolar alkanes listed (2-methylpropane, propane, methane). [Source: Chem LibreTexts](https://chem.libretexts.org/Bookshelves/General_Chemistry/Map%3A_Chemistry_-_The_Central_Science_(Brown_et_al.)/11%3A_Liquids_and_Intermolecular_Forces/11.02%3A_Intermolecular_Forces)
